title: xen-hypervisor-4.1-amd64: pygrub fails due to invalid opcode trapped

sentences.text: Whenever I try to start a domU, xm create failed for
Error: Boot loader didn't return any data!
It seems related to the following error in dmesg
[1440.163935] pygrub[3654] trap invalid opcode ip:7f732a997c50 sp:7fff60eb2258 error:0 in ld-2.13.so[7f732a984000+1f000]
Note that pygrub does NOT fail If I launch 'pygrub mydisk.img' on a standard
kernel boot, only if the hypervisor is used (tested with linux-image-3.0.0  and linux-image-2.39.2)
Here are logs taken from xend.log
[2011-11-20 09:01:11 2779] ERROR (XendBootloader:214) Boot loader didn't return any data!
VmError: Boot loader didn't return any data!
On Sun, 2011-11-20 at 09:08 +0100, Alexandre Vaissire wrote:
> Whenever I try to start a domU, xm create failed for
> Error: Boot loader didn't return any data!
> It seems related to the following error in dmesg
> [1440.163935] pygrub[3654] trap invalid opcode ip:7f732a997c50 sp:7fff60eb2258 error:0 in ld-2.13.so[7f732a984000+1f000]
An invalid op from the dynamic linker could be a more general bug or a bug in the python interpreter, but lets try and confirm before we pass this on.
> Note that pygrub does NOT fail If I launch 'pygrub mydisk.img' on a standard
> kernel boot, only if the hypervisor is used (tested with linux-image-3.0.0 >  and linux-image-2.39.2)
Since this is the actual command which is failing.
You might want to replace /var/run/xend/boot/xenbl.8881 with your own temp file (which you will need to touch first).
Having done that (and assuming it does repro the issue) can you run under gdb to see where the crash really is.
>> Note that pygrub does NOT fail If I launch 'pygrub mydisk.img' on a standard
>> kernel boot, only if the hypervisor is used (tested with linux-image-3.0.0 >>  and linux-image-2.39.2)
result is the same: there is no output in /tmp/pipo
> Since this is the actual command which is failing.
> Having done that (and assuming it does repro the issue) can you run > under gdb to see where the crash really is.

> result is the same: there is no output in /tmp/pipo
> Program received signal SIGILL, Illegal instruction.
All this adresses should be within the data section, where nothing should be executable.
> Let me know if you want some more info.
Pleast install libc6-dbg, make sure you have an uptodate system and call "disassemble" when it dies.
> Pleast install libc6-dbg, make sure you have an uptodate system and call > "disassemble" when it dies.

I can't reproduce this on my system.
ii  libc6                                                 2.13-11                                               Embedded GNU C Library: Shared libraries
ii  python2.7                                             2.7.2-3                                               An interactive high-level object-oriented language (version 2.7)
Looking at the eglibc source (2.13-21) x86_64/dl-trampoline.S:139 is:
(I think upgraded to 2.13-21 just in case, no change)
and let's keep it that way."
On Tue, 2011-11-22 at 13:18 +0000, Ian Campbell wrote:
> Looking at the eglibc source (2.13-21) x86_64/dl-trampoline.S:139 is:
This appears to be an AVX instruction which none of my test systems appear to support which is probably why I cannot reproduce this.
Which dom0 kernel are you running?
If you boot the same kernel natively what happens when you run pygrub?
(this should work natively, although obviously you won't be able to actually start a VM).
Can you please provide /proc/cpuinfo and the output of dmesg for both the native and Xen case and in the xen case the output of "xl dmesg".
Lastly it might be worth trying xsave=0 on your hypervisor command line.
> On Tue, 2011-11-22 at 13:18 +0000, Ian Campbell wrote:
>> Looking at the eglibc source (2.13-21) x86_64/dl-trampoline.S:139 is:
> This appears to be an AVX instruction which none of my test systems > appear to support which is probably why I cannot reproduce this.
> Which dom0 kernel are you running?
Linux glamdring 3.0.0-1-amd64 #1 SMP Sat Aug 27 16:21:11 UTC 2011 x86_64
> If you boot the same kernel natively what happens when you run pygrub?
> (this should work natively, although obviously you won't be able to > actually start a VM).
Yes it does work: I see the grub interface.
> Can you please provide /proc/cpuinfo and the output of dmesg for both > the native and Xen case and in the xen case the output of "xl dmesg".
See both files (report, report_xen) added to this mail.
> Lastly it might be worth trying xsave=0 on your hypervisor command line.
I noticed an kernel upgrade was just available (3.1.0-1).
On Tue, 2011-11-22 at 21:14 +0100, Alexandre Vaissire wrote:
> > On Tue, 2011-11-22 at 13:18 +0000, Ian Campbell wrote:
> >> Looking at the eglibc source (2.13-21) x86_64/dl-trampoline.S:139 is:
> > This appears to be an AVX instruction which none of my test systems > > appear to support which is probably why I cannot reproduce this.
> > Which dom0 kernel are you running?
> Linux glamdring 3.0.0-1-amd64 #1 SMP Sat Aug 27 16:21:11 UTC 2011 x86_64
> > If you boot the same kernel natively what happens when you run pygrub?
> > (this should work natively, although obviously you won't be able to > > actually start a VM).
> Yes it does work: I see the grub interface.
What happens if you pass "noxsave" to the native kernel?

I think the underlying bug here is that libc is only checking for the AVX cpuid feature bit but the presence of that bit does not necessarily imply that the OS is prepared to deal with userspace using AVX.
The Intel manuals[0] suggest (in section 13.5 "DETECTION OF AVX
INSTRUCTIONS") that the appropriate sequence to use from userspace to detect AVX is:
Issue XGETBV and verify that XCR0[2:1] = 11b (XMM state and
YMM state are enabled by OS).
If I am right then using "noxsave" on native should demonstrate the issue as well and show that there is a bug in libc.
However that doesn't rule out a bug in the hypervisor as well since it should support xsave...
except I've just noticed that xsave is deliberately disabled in Xen 4.1!
It has been re-enabled in xen-unstable with the comment "re-enable xsave by default now that it supports live migration" (so it will work in 4.2 when it is released).
This suggests that you could try with "xsave=1" on your hypervisor command line (but that migration won't work).
Current Noise: Callenish Circle - Soul Messiah
Writing free verse is like playing tennis with the net down.
On Wed, 2011-11-23 at 14:08 +0000, Ian Campbell wrote:
> The Intel manuals[0] suggest (in section 13.5 "DETECTION OF AVX
> INSTRUCTIONS") that the appropriate sequence to use from userspace to > detect AVX is:
Issue XGETBV and verify that XCR0[2:1] = 11b (XMM state and
>         YMM state are enabled by OS).
> If I am right then using "noxsave" on native should demonstrate the > issue as well and show that there is a bug in libc.
Which seems to already be reported and fixed upstream:
as well as against glibc in Debian http://bugs.debian.org/646549.
The fix is fixed in glibc-package SVN so ought to be fixed with the next upload (2.13-22).
Current Noise: Callenish Circle - My Hate Unfolds
